head.title: Lure the Best to a Life of Teaching

hedline.hl1: Lure the Best to a Life of Teaching

abstract.p: Michael Zerella letter on Harold O Levy's Sept 9 article deplores paperwork and meetings that draw teachers' energies away from students

block.p: Re ''Why the Best Don't Teach,'' by Harold O. Levy (Op-Ed, Sept. 9):
Re ''Why the Best Don't Teach,'' by Harold O. Levy (Op-Ed, Sept. 9):

Most would-be teachers are not only scared off by the low salaries but also by the paperwork and meetings that draw their energies away from their students. The goal of a teacher is not to make gobs of money, but rather to educate and inspire the next generation. The more they are allowed to do that as opposed to doing district-imposed busywork, the more likely they are to be satisfied with their career choice.

These days, private-sector companies that are competing for workers try to entice the best applicants with more than just salary. The intangibles like work environment, appreciation and support balanced with freedom are a big part of a person's decision. Let teachers do what they are good at, and don't force them to be part of a stifling bureaucracy.
The writer is a teacher at a charter high school.
